reviewText:

In this case, I let the Random Gods decide and the lord has choosen me the pink haired loli.
And I said.
Okay.
After struggling through the counter attack hell. I finally came out victorious.
And I was rewarded with loli bikinis and big tiddies.

After my right arm was sapped of strength, I sat back and thought to myself.
What a reward.

reviewText:
Product received for free

While it may be an 'Anime' Fighting game it plays more like your traditional 2D Capcom or SNK fighter. Moves have huge recovery and not everything is cancellable, on block you’ll always be minus, meaning you have to be smart with your button choice. Frame traps are non-existent because of this outside of chaining jabs together. The lack of air dash, air blocking and constant pressure separates this from the ‘anime’ style of game. Don’t worry though you have massive supers that do 40% and show the ladies in all their glory.

The game is a counterhit paradise; if you’ve played SFV it’s similar to crush counters except this whole game revolves around it. Without counter hit you might be doing 15%-20% damage, on CH we’re talking 40-75% damage depending on your resources.

Overall it’s very easy to pick up and play, you can freestyle for the most part and a lot of the characters have universal systems. Training mode is solid and with a large cast size with vary archetypes that all feel awesome to play. The input system is incredibly easy also; each character has 3 special moves, 1 super and another super that can only be done during the CH/CrushCounter state. There’s universal overheads, launchers and sweeps, allowing you to jump between characters and have an understanding with no problem.

The major problem is this game has been out for some time on the JPN PSN and even longer in arcades, you might have a hard time finding games outside of launch. There are also not many resources, so unless you’re ready to create your own combos or scour YouTube to find them you’ll be in trouble. With SFV being the mess that it is it’s not a bad time to try and explore other fighting games, in saying that you might be better off trying popular anime games such as Guilty Gear or BlazBlue.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Koihime Enbu is a fast paced  2d anime style fighting game featuring a cast of all females with variety of weapons and flash abilities. Comes with upbeat music and learnable universal inputs for all characters. Great fighting games for those who wants to get into the fighting genre. The game doesn't have any complex combos or technical skills such as air guards etc but can be challenging enough that veterans can pull off some freestyle combos using bounce and stun techniques.


Video Review https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dVwPe9Xlkhc

Pros + Cast of character
+ Solid training mode
+ Universal inputs for moves
+ Cast of characters waifus
+ Fast paced Combat system
+ Easy to understand and pick up, Complex enough for in depth combos+
+ Decent netcode
+ Game will level up your skills in footsies (Poking), counter hitting, and long recovery punishments making you think before you make a move. The sort of thing that will make you better in other fighting games.

Cons - The amount of players available online to play against thus matchmaking can be a pain   [Due to possibly the price]
- The story based on a visual novel so you really have to play that to get any of the plot going on
- Animation is good but can be much better.
- lack of variety of special moves

I enjoyed the game and think its worth the support though if you cannot afford it atm wait for sale but overall it is a solid fighting game for those of you that aren't into  complex combos and technicalities.

reviewText:
Easy to get into, but hard to master. The combat revolves around the basics, meaning knowing when to charge in or hold back and being able to string in small combos whenever the opportunity presents itself, will earn you victory. Like most Anime-style fighters you are able to combine dizzyingly long combos but it requires to make use of the high-risk, high Reward Fatal Counter system. The Fatal Counter system can be triggered by counter-attacking with Slow/Heavy attacks that  give opponents a larger window of opportunity for quick jabs+special moves, showing the need for patience and proper timing.

Like most fighters nowadays, Koihime Enbu has a training mode in which players can test out moves against CPU opponents in a variety of situations (crouching, jumping ect...) The training mode also acts as the challenge mode that goes from basic special moves to longer complicated combos.

Each character has a limited but diverse moveset which can be used with different tactics, giving each character a unique feel. Along with the 13 characters, there is also a choice between 2 tacticians per faction Shoku (Kan'u, Bachou ,Chō'un, Chōhi),  Gi (Sōsō, Kakōton, Kakōen, Gakushin) and Go (Sonken, Sonshōkō, Kannei, Shūtai) with the exception of Ryofu who only gets 1. Tacticians can fit a variety of purposes from being able to prolong combos  to the ability to create an opening needed to gain ground.

There is a scenario mode that includes dialogue before and after a fight that can somewhat show the relationship between characters, but in order to fully understand, prior knowledge from the Visual novels (or anime at least) is required. By completing a Character scenario you are rewarded with an event and a gorgeous CG that will be added to the  In-game gallery.

Overall, Koihime Enbu is a solid 2D fighter thats great for beginners and advanced players, being able to teach the core skills needed in any fighting game and still provide a decent challenge.

reviewText:
A lot of focus on art and visuals but not much on gameplay mechanics and balance.

It's fun on a casual, non-competitive level. And I don't mean competitive as in EVO or tryhards, I mean competitive as in I want to fight my opponent on fair ground in a well balanced arena and win by my own merits and skill."

It's not even a case of character tiers or any particular character just outclassing the others
date: it's the fact that the universal systems are pretty weak. Things that you expect from other fighting games just aren't here.\n\nThe good news is that the skill floor is very low -- you can get by pretty well just mashing buttons
recommended: and inputs for specials/supers are absolutely no more difficult than a modern street fighter game.\n\nThe bad news is that the skill ceiling isn't particularly high

reviewText:
I was somewhat interested in this game in the past but it was only released in the japan.
I'm glad this has finally been localized and decided to pick it up and it's been really fun so far.

Gameplay:
Has alot to Street Fighter due to it the way it borrows some elements from it such as:
Small set of moves but technically doubled if count EX attacks.
EX special moves take 1 meter to strenghten the specials.
Maximum stock 4 meter that carry over to next round.


Combo strings are usually not too long and the longer ones use certain counter moves to stun, bounce of ground, wall bounce or make them airborne.

Each character can pick 1 of 2 assist partners available to them to take into battle that use up 1 meter when called to add some more depth/strategy how you go about each match.

Pros:
+Netcode thus far after 15 or so matches online = Good.
+60 FPS
+Beautiful sprites
+Good art style
+Great Sountrack
+Online rank match
+Player rooms for casual match up to 6 players per room
+Easy to map buttons - 2 options to map buttons in a config tool before launching game & also ingame settings. (easily recognized my Hori RAP4 for PS3/PS4  )


Cons:
-could use some more additional animation sprites to make the movement look smoother.
-no resolution option, options available are windowed or full screen only.
-Japanese voices only

- / +Small cast of characters but in a way its also pro as each one is unique.


Closing thoughts: If you're a fan of anime style fighting games or a fan of the Koihime series you'll enjoy this.
If you're looking for a deep fighitng game like Guilty Gear, Street Fighter or Blazblue you won't find as much as deph here but it's just enough to keep the game fun.

reviewText:
Product received for free

First thing you notice upon booting up the game is the fact the graphics are lovely HD sprites and its presented in 16:9 which is always nice when playing Japanese fighters.

The main roster is made up of a collection of buxom and at times possibly under-age anime girls accompanied by a selection of side characters that add to each characters abilities.

Each character also comes with a selection of colours and as you fight through the game via either the arcade or storyline mode you are treated to a bit of back story that fleshes out the characters.

Gameplay wise Koihime Enbu is a relatively simple fighter taking most of its cues from the Street Fighter series. Most of the moves are done by simple circle combos but the ease of performing special moves means that you can pick up and play immediately. The game is a port of the PS4 release and as such the on screen button combinations are all PlayStation which when using an Xbox controller is very confusing.

Gameplay is something of a cross between BlazBlue and Street Fighter 3. You have 4 special gauges that can be used to trigger a number of special moves ranging from using your secondary character to combo ending anime explosions.

There are a few little issues that I have with the game most notably being the odd difficulty curve. Even on hard the arcade mode is actually very easy with the difficulty only spiking on the last fight.

The other slight issue is that currently unless you are hoping to play locally multiplayer may be out of the question. I tried on many occasions to get an on-line multiplayer game going but alas each time it simply expired.

Overall Koihime Enbu is a decent fighting game and definitely one of the better indie fighters I have played in recent years. For fight fans it is a fun little game with a few little niggles that doesn't spoilt it overall. Definitely worth picking up if you are a fan of the genre and have some friends to play local multiplayer with.

You can checkout our video review this text review was based on here :  Video Review	[www.thegametutor.co.uk]

reviewText:
Product received for free

This review is for those of you who have barely played any fighting games, like myself.

Video version: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CkDtLswe3EE

I'm a massive Dynasty Warriors fan, so I had to check this out. The developers were kind enough to send me a review key for my channel, so I delved in expecting a mediocre fighting game, but I was wrong.

It has been one of the most incredible new and fresh experiences I have had the pleasure of having recently. Everything feels so responsive and it's so easy to pick up and play, even with very little fighting experience in the past. Not only will it show you the button guides for combos, but it'll give you a demonstration too, so every character is really easy to learn.

The story mode is filled with hilarious scenarios, that had me genuinely laughing and unexpectedly wanting to get through every single character's story just to see what happens. It's far from serious, but that gives a nice change from the usual Three Kingdoms products. The difficulty ramps up nicely, with a good challenge at the end of each path that will take some practice to overcome.

I can't speak for the netcode as online play isn't enabled yet, but I will update this review once the game has been released and I'm really looking forward to hopping into the multiplayer and getting my rear end handed to me.

It's expensive and honestly you don't get a huge amount of content for the price tag, but what you do get is incredible and will keep you entertained for a huge amount of time. If anyone has any questions, feel free to ask and I will answer to the best of my ability.

reviewText: It's nice to sink my teeth into a new fighting game, figuring out mechanics and discovering new characters.  Very enjoyable game, plays well and looks pretty good.  Yeah, it's one of THOSE anime games, but I'm sick of stereotypical BS.  Fun game, and yes I am a grown man with a wife and kids.  Recommended but it's kind of pricey.  Looking for a shiny new 2D fighter?  Check it out, I'm glad I did.

reviewText: I've never been able to get into fighting games, but this is definately one of the best ones i've played, so good infact that I have enjoyed it for more than 70 minutes which is about my attention span with most fighting games. The price on this game however may seem like its a bit much but honestly this offers more than Street Fighter V and that game is $60 pick it up no questions asked its well worth it.
